segment.target: Visual Studio tools for game programming

segment.source: An overview of DirectX specific tools available in Visual Studio.
segment.target: An overview of DirectX specific tools available in Visual Studio.

segment.target: Visual Studio tools for game programming

segment.source: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive

segment.source: Summary
segment.target: Summary

segment.source: Create a DirectX game project from a template
segment.target: Create a DirectX game project from a template

segment.source: Visual Studio tools for DirectX game programming
segment.target: Visual Studio tools for DirectX game programming

segment.source: If you use Visual Studio Ultimate to develop DirectX apps, there are additional tools available for creating, editing, previewing, and exporting image, model, and shader resources.
segment.target: If you use Visual Studio Ultimate to develop DirectX apps, there are additional tools available for creating, editing, previewing, and exporting image, model, and shader resources.

segment.source: There are also tools that you can use to convert resources at build time and debug DirectX graphics code.
segment.target: There are also tools that you can use to convert resources at build time and debug DirectX graphics code.

segment.source: This topic gives an overview of these graphics tools.
segment.target: This topic gives an overview of these graphics tools.

segment.source: Image Editor
segment.target: Image Editor

segment.source: Use the Image Editor to work with the kinds of rich texture and image formats that DirectX uses.
segment.target: Use the Image Editor to work with the kinds of rich texture and image formats that DirectX uses.

segment.source: The Image Editor supports the following formats.
segment.target: The Image Editor supports the following formats.

segment.source: .png
segment.target: .png

segment.source: .jpg, .jpeg, .jpe, .jfif
segment.target: .jpg, .jpeg, .jpe, .jfif

segment.source: .dds
segment.target: .dds

segment.source: .gif
segment.target: .gif

segment.source: .bmp
segment.target: .bmp

segment.source: .dib
segment.target: .dib

segment.source: .tif, .tiff
segment.target: .tif, .tiff

segment.source: .tga
segment.target: .tga

segment.source: Create build customization files to convert these to .dds files at build time.
segment.target: Create build customization files to convert these to .dds files at build time.

segment.source: For more information, see Working with Textures and Images.
segment.target: For more information, see Working with Textures and Images.

segment.source: Note The Image Editor is not intended to be a replacement for a full feature image editing app, but is appropriate for many simple viewing and editing scenarios.
segment.target: Note The Image Editor is not intended to be a replacement for a full feature image editing app, but is appropriate for many simple viewing and editing scenarios.

segment.source: Model Editor
segment.target: Model Editor

segment.source: You can use the Model Editor to create basic 3D models from scratch, or to view and modify more-complex 3D models from full-featured 3D modeling tools.
segment.target: You can use the Model Editor to create basic 3D models from scratch, or to view and modify more-complex 3D models from full-featured 3D modeling tools.

segment.source: The Model Editor supports several 3D model formats that are used in DirectX app development.
segment.target: The Model Editor supports several 3D model formats that are used in DirectX app development.

segment.source: You can create build customization files to convert these to .cmo files at build time.
segment.target: You can create build customization files to convert these to .cmo files at build time.

segment.source: .fbx
segment.target: .fbx

segment.source: .dae
segment.target: .dae

segment.source: .obj
segment.target: .obj

segment.source: Here's a screenshot of a model in the editor with lighting applied.
segment.target: Here's a screenshot of a model in the editor with lighting applied.

segment.source: teapot
segment.target: teapot

segment.source: For more information, see Working with 3-D Models.
segment.target: For more information, see Working with 3-D Models.

segment.source: Note The Model Editor is not intended to be a replacement for a full feature model editing app, but is appropriate for many simple viewing and editing scenarios.
segment.target: Note The Model Editor is not intended to be a replacement for a full feature model editing app, but is appropriate for many simple viewing and editing scenarios.

segment.source: Shader Designer
segment.target: Shader Designer

segment.source: Use the Shader Designer to create custom visual effects for your game or app even if you don't know HLSL programming.
segment.target: Use the Shader Designer to create custom visual effects for your game or app even if you don't know HLSL programming.

segment.source: You create a shader visually as a graph.
segment.target: You create a shader visually as a graph.

segment.source: Each node displays a preview of the output up to that operation.
segment.target: Each node displays a preview of the output up to that operation.

segment.source: Here's an example that applies Lambert lighting with a sphere preview.
segment.target: Here's an example that applies Lambert lighting with a sphere preview.

segment.source: visual shader graph
segment.target: visual shader graph

segment.source: Use the Shader Editor to design, edit, and save shaders in the .dgsl format.
segment.target: Use the Shader Editor to design, edit, and save shaders in the .dgsl format.

segment.source: It also exports the following formats.
segment.target: It also exports the following formats.

segment.source: .hlsl (source code)
segment.target: .hlsl (source code)

segment.source: .cso (bytecode)
segment.target: .cso (bytecode)

segment.source: .h (HLSL bytecode array)
segment.target: .h (HLSL bytecode array)

segment.source: Create build customization files to convert any of these formats to .cso files at build time.
segment.target: Create build customization files to convert any of these formats to .cso files at build time.

segment.source: Here is a portion of HLSL code that is exported by the Shader Editor.
segment.target: Here is a portion of HLSL code that is exported by the Shader Editor.

segment.source: This is only the code for the Lambert lighting node.
segment.target: This is only the code for the Lambert lighting node.

segment.source: For more information, see Working with Shaders.
segment.target: For more information, see Working with Shaders.

segment.source: Build customizations for 3D assets
segment.target: Build customizations for 3D assets

segment.source: You can add build customizations to your project so that Visual Studio converts resources to usable formats.
segment.target: You can add build customizations to your project so that Visual Studio converts resources to usable formats.

segment.source: After that, you can load the assets into your app and use them by creating and filling DirectX resources just like you would in any other DirectX app.
segment.target: After that, you can load the assets into your app and use them by creating and filling DirectX resources just like you would in any other DirectX app.

segment.source: To add a build customization, you right-click on the project in the Solution Explorer and select Build Customizations....
segment.target: To add a build customization, you right-click on the project in the Solution Explorer and select Build Customizations....

segment.source: You can add the following types of build customizations to your project.
segment.target: You can add the following types of build customizations to your project.

segment.source: Image Content Pipeline takes image files as input and outputs DirectDraw Surface (.dds) files.
segment.target: Image Content Pipeline takes image files as input and outputs DirectDraw Surface (.dds) files.

segment.source: Mesh Content Pipeline takes mesh files (such as .fbx) and outputs .cmo mesh files.
segment.target: Mesh Content Pipeline takes mesh files (such as .fbx) and outputs .cmo mesh files.

segment.source: Shader Content Pipeline takes Visual Shader Graph (.dgsl) from the Visual Studio Shader Editor and outputs a Compiled Shader Output (.cso) file.
segment.target: Shader Content Pipeline takes Visual Shader Graph (.dgsl) from the Visual Studio Shader Editor and outputs a Compiled Shader Output (.cso) file.

segment.source: For more information, see Using 3-D Assets in Your Game or App.
segment.target: For more information, see Using 3-D Assets in Your Game or App.

segment.source: Debugging DirectX graphics
segment.target: Debugging DirectX graphics

segment.source: Visual Studio provides graphics-specific debugging tools.
segment.target: Visual Studio provides graphics-specific debugging tools.

segment.source: Use these tools to debug things like:
segment.target: Use these tools to debug things like:

segment.source: The graphics pipeline.
segment.target: The graphics pipeline.

segment.source: The event call stack.
segment.target: The event call stack.

segment.source: The object table.
segment.target: The object table.

segment.source: The device state.
segment.target: The device state.

segment.source: Shader bugs.
segment.target: Shader bugs.

segment.source: Uninitialized or incorrect constant buffers and parameters.
segment.target: Uninitialized or incorrect constant buffers and parameters.

segment.source: DirectX version compatibility.
segment.target: DirectX version compatibility.

segment.source: Limited Direct2D support.
segment.target: Limited Direct2D support.

segment.source: Operating system and SDK requirements.
segment.target: Operating system and SDK requirements.

segment.source: For more information, see Debugging DirectX Graphics.
segment.target: For more information, see Debugging DirectX Graphics.

segment.source: Note This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: Note This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

segment.source: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.
segment.target: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.
